title: Synthetic Recap
body:
CHARLOTTE, N.C. (AP) — In a performance for the ages, Reggie Miller didn't just beat the Charlotte Hornets; he carved his name into the record books with a scoring clinic that left the Charlotte Coliseum in a state of stunned silence.

Miller, the Indiana Pacers' sharpshooting legend, erupted for a career-high and franchise-record 47 points, single-handedly powering his team to a 106-95 victory. From the opening tip, it was clear this was Miller’s night. He was an unstoppable force, a whirlwind of motion and dead-eye precision that the Hornets had no answer for.

The game was not a blowout; it was a systematic dismantling by one man. While Charlotte’s Glen Rice put up a valiant 29-point effort of his own, he was merely a soloist competing against a symphony conducted by Miller. Every time the Hornets threatened to close the gap, Miller would respond with a cold-blooded three-pointer or slice through the lane for a dagger of a basket.

His final line was a thing of beauty: 47 points on 14-of-26 shooting, including a scorching 6-of-11 from beyond the arc. He was perfect, 13-for-13, from the free-throw line, each swish adding another punctuation mark to his historic statement.

The Pacers, as a team, were merely the supporting cast for this virtuoso performance. They fed the hot hand, set the screens, and watched in awe as Miller put on a show that transcended a simple regular-season win. This was a night where one player’s greatness was so overwhelming that it became the entire narrative, a legendary outing that will be remembered long after the final score is forgotten.
